data.title: 1000+ American Poems (Poems 286
data.meta_description: American poets have been influential in shaping poetry as a form of expression and have contributed to the development of modernism and postmodernism.
data.text:
PDF Guide

Looking for the Gulf Motel

by Richard Blanco

‘Looking for the Gulf Motel’ by Richard Blanco explores memories and loss through an autobiographical lens. The poet reflects on a family vacation to a Floridian island 30 years ago, contrasting it with the present by noting significant changes in both the environment and his own life as he revisits the location.

Richard Blanco's poems, including 'Looking for the Gulf Motel,' rose to popularity amongst Americans by virtue of their originality and specificity as they regard Blanco's experience as a Cuban-American. Blanco, being one of the poets to read his poem at a Presidential election, also elevated his poems in American circles. 'Looking for the Gulf Motel' in particular, is still widely received and analyzed today at American schools and universities.

I am thirty-eight, driving up Collier Boulevard,

looking for The Gulf Motel, for everything

that should still be, but isn’t...

PDF Guide

Matins [What is my heart to you]

by Louise Glück

‘Matins [What is my heart to you]’ by Louise Glück implores god to pacify the speaker’s anguish and the solitude that has exacerbated it.

Glück has been compared to several seminal American poets including Emily Dickinson. She often explored deeply personal topics in her verses but used terse language that was not without moments of beautifully enlightening imagery or figurative language. Scenes rooted in nature and mythology, as well as religion, appear often in works like this one.

What is my heart to you

that you must break it over and over

like a plantsman testing

his new species? Practice

PDF Guide

Maud Muller

by John Greenleaf Whittier

‘Maud Muller’ by John Greenleaf Whittier is a classic narrative ballad that recounts how the poor peasant, Maud, and an urban judge fantasize about getting married and living together. However, neither of them ever takes action, which fills their lives with regret.

The form and structure of this poem are rather typical of Romantic-era ballads, but this verse is unique in that it is an American pastoral Ballad. While the poets overseas in England were writing stories a lot like Maud's in their poetry, Whittier often put an American spin on his poems, rooting his scenes and images in the common experiences of American commoners.

God pity them both! and pity us all,

Who vainly the dreams of youth recall.

For of all sad words of tongue or pen,

The saddest are these: “It might have been!”

PDF Guide

Medusa

by Louise Bogan

‘Medusa’ by Louise Bogan describes an encounter the speaker has with the eyes of Medusa and the eternal results of that meeting.

When the bare eyes were before me

And the hissing hair,

Held up at a window, seen through a door.

The stiff bald eyes, the serpents on the forehead

Formed in the air.

PDF Guide

Morning Swim

by Maxine Kumin

‘Morning Swim’ by Maxine Kumin is a thoughtful lyric poem that’s written in couplets. The poem engages with themes of God and Nature.

Maxine Kumin is an American poet, known for her clear portrayal of nature and human relationships. Her work deeply explores themes relevant to her American context, capturing a unique blend of personal and communal experiences. This poem is a fine example of her style, integrating elements of the American landscape and personal reflection.

Into my empty head there come

a cotton beach, a dock wherefrom

I set out, oily and nude

through mist, in chilly solitude.

PDF Guide

Opportunity

by Helen Hunt Jackson

‘Opportunity’ by Helen Hunt Jackson depicts one person’s encounter with a rapturous and divinely-given vision.

Jackson was born in 1830 and died five decades later in 1884. She was an extremely religious woman who supported better treatment of Indigenous people living in U.S. territories and states. Her poetry often concerned itself with ruminations on religion and nature.

I do not know if, climbing some steep hill,

Through fragrant wooded pass, this glimpse I bought,

Or whether in some mid-day I was caught

To upper air, where visions of God’s will

PDF Guide

Our Martyred Soldiers

by Paul Laurence Dunbar

‘Our Martyred Soldiers’ by Paul Laurence Dunbar is a moving poem that searches for consolation in the wake of the deaths of noble men.

Dunbar was an American poet and is remembered for his moving verse and powerful illustrations of life as a person of color in post-Civil War society. Not all his poems or novels deal with the effects of racism, yet poems like this one are clearly reflective of the effects such conflicts had.

In homes all green, but cold in death,

Robbed of the blessed boon of breath —

Resting in peace from field and fray,

Our martyred soldiers sleeping lay.

PDF Guide

Outward Bound

by Helen Hunt Jackson

‘Outward Bound’ by Helen Hunt Jackson is a rousing sonnet that dispels one’s fears of traveling into the unknown with a reminder that we make the same bold excursions every day of our lives without ever acknowledging it.

Jackson was born in Amherst, MA in 1830 and died 54 years later in San Francisco, CA. As both a writer and poet she documented a wide range of American subjects that, for better or worse, she helped mythologize. This is a good, although not particularly famous example of American poetry.

The hour has come. Strong hands the anchor raise;

Friends stand and weep along the fading shore,

In sudden fear lest we return no more,

In sudden fancy thaThe safer stays

PDF Guide

Prayers of Steel

by Carl Sandburg

‘Prayers of Steel’ by Carl Sandburg is an original poem. In it, the poet focuses on the imagined dreams of steel.

Carl Sandburg was an American poet, and his work often centered on the ordinary aspects of American life. In ‘Prayers of Steel,’ Sandburg personifies steel, showing its hopes and desires. This approach connects deeply with readers by portraying the steel’s ambitions as a reflection of human aspirations and struggles.

Lay me on an anvil, O God.

Beat me and hammer me into a steel spike.

Drive me into the girders that hold a skyscraper together.

Take red-hot rivets and fasten me into the central girders.

PDF Guide

Refusal

by Maya Angelou

‘Refusal’ by Maya Angelou is a powerful love poem that speaks of one person’s dedication to another. It features a speaker’s beliefs about how long she’s loved one person and how that love needs to continue into her next life.

Maya Angelou is an incredibly important American poet who, throughout her life, wrote a number of incredibly famous poems. All of her poetry, including tis piece, is important in the history of American poetry although this poem is not her best-known.

Beloved,

In what other lives or lands

Have I known your lips

Your Hands

PDF Guide

Shakespearean Sonnet

by R. S. Gwynn

‘Shakespearean Sonnet’ by R. S. Gwynn is a celebration of Shakespeare’s plays. Each line of the poem refers to a different tragedy, comedy, or history play.

R. S. Gwynn is an American poet known for his inventive and humorous takes on classic literature. In ‘Shakespearean Sonnet,’ he creatively summarizes Shakespeare’s plays without naming them directly, showing a unique blend of respect for and playfulness with classic texts. His work captures the essence of Shakespeare in a modern and engaging way.

A man is haunted by his father’s ghost.

Boy meets girl while feuding families fight.

A Scottish king is murdered by his host.

Two couples get lost on a summer night.

PDF Guide

Song of the Open Road

by Ogden Nash

‘Song of the Open Road’ by Ogden Nash is a short but humorous poem that expresses an annoyance and anxiety over the prevalence of billboards over trees.

Nash was an American writer whose fame extended beyond poetry and the written word. He was known as a lyricist for Broadway musicals and even made appearances on both comedy and radio shows. But his poetry endures because of its playfully sardonic musings and inventive rhymes, which sometimes even deliberately misspelled words.

I think that I shall never see

A billboard lovely as a tree

PDF Guide

That Music Always Round Me

by Walt Whitman

‘That Music Always Round Me’ by Walt Whitman is a beautiful poem that melds together the poet’s democratic worldview with a rapt appreciation for individual beauty.

As a revered member of the Transcendental movement in America, Whitman's poems represent an important but complicated legacy. His pioneering verse sought to wrangle all the diverse elements of the nation into an ecstatic expression of democratic zeal. Although those sentiments weren't always reflected in his other writings, poems like this one celebrate the plurality of the nation.

That music always round me, unceasing, unbeginning, yet long untaught I did not hear,

But now the chorus I hear and am elated,

PDF Guide

The Flower

by Robert Creeley

In ‘The Flower,’ Robert Creeley meditates upon a full-blooded flower and tries to fill his soul with its spiritual energy. He creates a contrast between awakening and ignorance through the image of the “patient flower.”

Robert Creeley was an American poet whose work includes the poem ‘The Flower.’ His poetry is notable for its clear and direct style, reflecting his American background. ‘The Flower’ fits into the 20th-century literary scene by addressing themes of personal and spiritual growth with accessible language and imagery.

Remember the way you

hunched up the first

times in bed, all your

body as you walked
